posts.content:
The Vanity Scale Era for SaaS is over.

Vanity Scale Era (2020-2023):

- Revenue was just a metric to help raise more funding

- 90% of money went to hiring not value creation

- Focus on "scaling" without unit economics

- Headcount dominated board discussions

- Average startup burning through $50M+ rounds

- More employees meant more "growth"

- ROI measured in fundraising, not profit

- Every solution was just another burn rate to manage

The New World of SaaS: ‚ÄúCoffee Shop Test‚Äù Economics (2025-????):

- Revenue isn't the metric‚Äîit's profit per employee

- $860K revenue per employee drives 47% margins

- Focus on customer value and capital efficiency

- Systems generate profit and scale organically

- Solutions that multiply impact, not just add costs

- One focused team (5 people) doing the work of 200

- ROI measured in pure profit and customer value

- Smart execution largely replaces bloated operations

As the growing contingent of lean team, bootstrapped SaaS founders is proving:

We're not just changing how SaaS gets built‚Äîwe're changing who builds it.

This is a complete re-ordering of the startup playbook.

It's going to be difficult for many to navigate ("but how will you scale?" cries the VC).

The answer: build businesses that don't burn cash but create value.

And when building a real business, the ‚ÄúCoffee Shop Test‚Äù is your guiding light:

Would I approve this cost if I was sitting in a coffee shop, looking at my personal bank account?

There's no going back. The only way out is through.

And in 2025 and beyond into the era of AI, bootstrappers and builders win.

This is the ‚ÄúCoffee Shop Test‚Äù Economics Era

Great VP of Sales, first day:

- identifies top existing talent, does what it takes to keep them
- begins to move out underperformers

Mediocre VP of Sales, first month:

- top talent leaves
- tries hard to keep everyone

comments.commentText: More here: https://www.saastr.com/the-30-day-test-how-to-know-if-your-vp-of-sales-will-succeed/

Before moving out underperformers, a great VP of Sales identifies why they‚Äôre underperforming‚Äînot just putting them on a PIP. Have they been properly trained in a way that works for them? It's far costlier to replace people than to train, mentor, and equip them with skills tailored to how they learn. I inherited a team with few top performers and adjusted quotas to be consistent, offering daily call reviews, upselling training, and relationship-building techniques. The result? Skyrocketing sales, loyal clients, and confident, overachieving reps‚Äîsaving the company hundreds of thousands and taking the sales team from bottom of the pile to #1 across the country. What it made me do is review the Regional Manager skills....that was my next project.
Yes but many think they can do this and can't. And most CEOs don't really know what to expect here.

And now Microsoft jumps on the low-performer bandwagon:

"They also specified that these layoffs were unrelated to the cuts announced last week that focused on underperforming workers. "At Microsoft we focus on high-performance talent," the spokesperson said (via CNBC). "We are always working on helping people learn and grow. When people are not performing, we take appropriate action.""

Job seekers, please I'm begging you...button up your references!! This bias is getting out of hand!!

comments.commentText:
Maybe Microsoft needs to revisit the "Lost Decade" article by Vanity Fair.

Managers end up making decisions on who lands on the cut list, regardless of performance, and it leads to high turnover of IC employees, and bloat in management. Managers aren't going to vote themselves out of a job, and the competition and pressure to move up into that 'safe' position leads to a glut of people "managing" the work without anyone left to actually get it done.
Genna Zerzan precisely.

When a tech giant publicly frames layoffs as "removing underperforming workers" while emphasizing their "focus on high-performance talent," they're not just cutting jobs - they're sabotaging their former employees' futures. Imagine being a solid performer for years, contributing to major projects, only to have your employer retroactively label you as "low performing" during layoffs. Now you're forced to walk into every job interview with this cloud hanging over you, having to defend your capabilities against a narrative you never got to counter. This isn't about performance management - it's about companies protecting their stock price and image by throwing their departing employees under the bus. Using layoffs as an excuse to tarnish the reputations of the very people who helped build your company.
To anyone affected: You don't owe future employers an explanation for corporate spin. Your worth isn't determined by an exit PR strategy.
Tracey Scott true!!

7 Simple Steps to Create Highly Engaged Teams 

Building a highly engaged team is essential for driving success, fostering innovation, and maintaining a positive workplace culture. Here are 7 Simple Steps to elevate your team's engagement and performance:

 Provide Clear Direction

Set Clear Expectations: Ensure your team understands their roles, responsibilities, and the overall vision.
Communicate Goals: Regularly share updates and progress to keep everyone aligned and focused.
 Make Goals Aspirational

Inspire Ambition: Set challenging yet achievable goals that motivate your team to strive for excellence.
Celebrate Milestones: Recognize and celebrate when goals are met to boost morale and encourage continued effort.
 Empower Them to Succeed

Delegate Authority: Trust your team with the autonomy to make decisions and take ownership of their work.
Provide Resources: Ensure they have the tools and support needed to excel in their roles.
Ô∏è Create a Safe Environment

Foster Trust: Encourage open communication and create a space where team members feel safe to express ideas and concerns.
Promote Inclusivity: Ensure everyone feels valued and included, regardless of their background or role.
 Give Them Space

Encourage Creativity: Allow your team the freedom to explore new ideas and approaches without micromanagement.
Respect Work-Life Balance: Support flexible working arrangements to help team members maintain a healthy balance.
 Provide Support

Be Approachable: Make yourself available to offer guidance, feedback, and assistance whenever needed.
Invest in Development: Offer training and development opportunities to help your team grow professionally.
 Give Recognition

Acknowledge Achievements: Regularly recognize and reward your team's hard work and accomplishments.
Show Appreciation: Simple gestures of appreciation can significantly boost morale and motivation.
 Why It Matters: Engaged teams are more productive, innovative, and committed to achieving organizational goals. By implementing these simple steps, you can create a thriving work environment where your team feels valued and motivated to excel.
